results:
The search returned comprehensive information about Gulliver's Travels in Poland, including Polish translations and adaptations titled "Podróże Guliwera." Here's what the search revealed:

## Polish Translations and Adaptations

Podróże Guliwera (Gulliver's Travels) is the popular shortened title of Jonathan Swift's 1726 novel, which combines satire on human nature with parody of travel novels popular at that time.(no content)Polish translations of this work were done by, among others, Maciej Słomczyński.

The Wikipedia entry mentions several Polish translations:
- Podróże Gulliwera translated by Cecylia Niewiadomska (1929)
- Podróże Gulliwera translated by Jacek Bocheński and Marian Brandys (1981)

## Academic Research on Polish Adaptations

The search uncovered significant academic research examining Polish adaptations. A comparative study analyzed two adaptations of Gulliver's Travels published at the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries: a Polish version by Aleksandra Callier (1908) and a Ladino version by Alexander Ben Ghiat (1897).(no content)Aleksandra Callier published "Przygody Guliwera w kraju karłów i olbrzymów" (Gulliver's Adventures in the Land of Dwarfs and Giants) in Warsaw through Wydawnictwo "Księgarni Popularnej" in 1908.

The academic analysis revealed that the Polish version showed significantly more domestication contrasting with the universalizing effect of removing realia in the Ladino version.(no content)The analysis shows that the Polish version is strongly domesticated as opposed to the Ladino version which stripped of most realia acquires a universal character. Both versions fall within the framework of the adventure story genre.

## Reception History

Academic research exists on Polish reception, including "No Swift beyond Gulliver: Notes on the Polish Reception" in The Reception of Jonathan Swift in Europe.(no content)Due to often drastic fragments, the book has been adapted into numerous variants for different readers. The original book is a sharp, brutal satire.

## Modern Editions and Adaptations

Modern Polish editions include bilingual adaptations for English language learners. "Czytamy w oryginale" is a publishing series containing adaptations of the greatest works of English-language literature. The bilingual adaptation of the novel is an attractive aid for English learners. Following the characters' fates, we can continuously compare the English and Polish text.(no content)The bilingual adaptation of "Gulliver's Travels / Podróże Guliwera" by Jonathan Swift is an attractive aid for English learners. Following the novel's characters, we can continuously compare the English and Polish text. The adaptation was prepared with intermediate readers in mind, but thanks to the bilingual version, readers just beginning to learn English can also use the book.

The search also revealed cultural references, including Jacek Kaczmarski creating a song cycle titled "Podróże Guliwera" consisting of four songs describing each journey, which appeared on the album "Dzieci Hioba."
